raw_text: These knowledge structures, comparable to scripts (Schank and Abelson, 1977) or narrative chains (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2008), describe typical sequences of events in a particular context. Given the number of potential scripts, their development by hand becomes a resource intensive process. In the past, some work has been devoted to automatically construct script-like structures from compiled corpora (Fujiki et al, 2003) (Chambers and Juraf sky, 2008)
clean_text: These knowledge structures, comparable to scripts (Schank and Abelson, 1977) or narrative chains (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2008), describe typical sequences of events in a particular context. Given the number of potential scripts, their development by hand becomes a resource intensive process. In the past, some work has been devoted to automatically construct script-like structures from compiled corpora (Fujiki et al, 2003) (Chambers and Jurafsky, 2008).

raw_text: Features 2 and 5 are inspired by the work of Chambers and Jurafsky (2008), who investigated unsupervised learning of narrative event sequences using point wise mutual information (PMI) between syntactic positions

raw_text: We could have obtained a more accurate ordering using a temporal classifier (see Chambers and Jurafsky 2008), however we leave this to future work. raw_text: Setup Following Chambers and Jurafsky (2008), we extracted and lemmatized the verbs from the New York Times section of the Gigaword Corpus using the Stanford POS tagger (Toutanova et al, 2004) and the Morphalemmatizer (Minnen et al, 2000)
